1_Introduction: Formulates contextual auction design with bidder and item features
Proposes CITransNet: context-integrated Transformer auction mechanism
Enforces permutation equivariance over bidders, items, and contexts
Uses size-invariant parameters to generalize across auction sizes
Provides sample complexity bound for mechanism generalization
Near-Myerson single-item; outperforms baselines on complex multi-item auctions
2.2_Contextual_Auction_Design_as_a_Learn: Formalize contextual auctions with bidder and item contexts in allocation and payments.
Target maximum expected revenue under DSIC and IR constraints.
Define ex-post regret; show DSIC equivalent to zero regret.
Provide sample-complexity bounds linking empirical and expected revenue and regret.
Learn mechanisms by minimizing empirical ex-post regret with IR constraints.
Parameterize allocation and payment rules; estimate expectations via samples.

4_Experiments: Evaluate CITransNet on single and multi-item contextual auctions, discrete and continuous
Compare against Item-wise Myerson, RegretNet, CREgretNet, and CEquivariantNet baselines
Achieves best revenue across all settings with regret under 0.003
Transformer interaction layer drives gains; matches near-optimal Myerson in single-item
Permutation-equivariant inductive bias improves over CREgretNet in large-scale auctions

5_Conclusion: Proposes CITransNet, a transformer-based architecture for contextual auctions
Ensures permutation equivariance to bids and contexts; handles asymmetric information
Recovers known optimal solutions in simple auctions
Validates transformer interaction layers vs. context-integrated RegretNet and EquivariantNet
Demonstrates out-of-setting generalization across varying bidders and items
Abstract: Proposes CITransNet: context-integrated transformer for auction design
Incorporates public bidder and item context into learning
Maintains permutation-equivariance over bids and contexts
Finds asymmetric mechanisms beyond symmetry-limited approaches
Recovers known optima in single-item auctions
Outperforms baselines and generalizes beyond training cases
